body_html:
The only question is the API -- would it take two tensors as input, the one to broadcast and one describing the shape?

NumPy's broadcast_to API basically works they way. It takes an array to broadcast and a tuple describing the shape. In TensorFlow the shape could either be a TensorShape object or tuple/list (used for static shape analysis), or a 1D tensor (for dynamic shapes).
body_text:
The only question is the API -- would it take two tensors as input, the one to broadcast and one describing the shape?

NumPy's broadcast_to API basically works they way. It takes an array to broadcast and a tuple describing the shape. In TensorFlow the shape could either be a TensorShape object or tuple/list (used for static shape analysis), or a 1D tensor (for dynamic shapes).
body:
> The only question is the API -- would it take two tensors as input, the one to broadcast and one describing the shape?

NumPy's `broadcast_to` API basically works they way. It takes an array to broadcast and a tuple describing the shape. In TensorFlow the shape could either be a TensorShape object or tuple/list (used for static shape analysis), or a 1D tensor (for dynamic shapes).
